items.title: I can identify and define amplitude, wavelength, period, and frequency of a wave
items.what: Amplitude (A) is the maximum displacement from the neutral position. Wavelength (λ) is the distance between repeated parts of the wave. Period (T) is the time for one complete wavelength to pass. Frequency (f) is the number of wavelengths passing a point per second.
items.why: These four quantities are the building blocks for describing any wave. Without them, we cannot quantify or compare different waves.
items.example: A water wave has crests 4.0 m apart (wavelength = 4.0 m), reaches 0.5 m above the calm water level (amplitude = 0.5 m), and 2 complete waves pass a pier every second (frequency = 2 Hz, period = 0.5 s).

subtopic.name: Wave Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental quantities used to describe waves: amplitude, wavelength, period, frequency, and speed. These properties allow us to mathematically describe and predict wave behaviour.
subtopic.why: Understanding wave properties is essential for analysing all wave phenomena, from sound and water waves to light and radio signals. These concepts form the foundation for the entire topic of electromagnetic radiation.

items.title: I can use the wave equation λ = v/f to calculate wavelength, frequency, or speed
items.what: The wave equation relates wavelength (λ), wave speed (v), and frequency (f). It can be rearranged to find any one quantity if the other two are known.
items.why: This equation is fundamental to wave physics and allows us to predict wave behaviour in different situations, from calculating radio wavelengths to understanding how light changes in different materials.
items.example: A wave has a frequency of 3.0 × 10⁹ Hz and a speed of 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. Using λ = v/f: λ = (3.0 × 10⁸)/(3.0 × 10⁹) = 0.10 m or 10 cm.

subtopic.name: Wave Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental quantities used to describe waves: amplitude, wavelength, period, frequency, and speed. These properties allow us to mathematically describe and predict wave behaviour.
subtopic.why: Understanding wave properties is essential for analysing all wave phenomena, from sound and water waves to light and radio signals. These concepts form the foundation for the entire topic of electromagnetic radiation.

items.title: I can use the relationship λ = vT to solve problems involving period
items.what: Since frequency and period are inversely related (f = 1/T), the wave equation can also be written as λ = vT, which is useful when period is given instead of frequency.
items.why: Some wave measurements provide period rather than frequency, such as timing ocean waves or heartbeats. This form of the equation allows direct calculation without first converting to frequency.
items.example: A wave travels at 16 km/s with a period of 0.40 s. Using λ = vT: λ = 16,000 × 0.40 = 6,400 m or 6.4 km.

subtopic.name: Wave Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental quantities used to describe waves: amplitude, wavelength, period, frequency, and speed. These properties allow us to mathematically describe and predict wave behaviour.
subtopic.why: Understanding wave properties is essential for analysing all wave phenomena, from sound and water waves to light and radio signals. These concepts form the foundation for the entire topic of electromagnetic radiation.

items.title: I can explain that wavelength depends on both the wave speed and the source frequency
items.what: The frequency of a wave is determined only by its source and does not change when the wave enters a different medium. The speed of a wave is determined by the medium. Therefore, wavelength must change when a wave enters a new medium.
items.why: This concept explains why light changes wavelength (and colour perception) in different materials, and why the same radio station has different wavelengths in air versus water.
items.example: A 500 Hz sound wave travels at 340 m/s in air (λ = 0.68 m) but at 1500 m/s in water. Since frequency stays at 500 Hz, the wavelength in water becomes λ = 1500/500 = 3.0 m.

subtopic.name: Wave Properties
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental quantities used to describe waves: amplitude, wavelength, period, frequency, and speed. These properties allow us to mathematically describe and predict wave behaviour.
subtopic.why: Understanding wave properties is essential for analysing all wave phenomena, from sound and water waves to light and radio signals. These concepts form the foundation for the entire topic of electromagnetic radiation.

items.title: I can distinguish between transverse and longitudinal waves
items.what: In transverse waves, particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave travel. In longitudinal waves, particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave travel, creating compressions and rarefactions.
items.why: This distinction affects how waves interact with barriers and openings. Transverse waves can be polarised (vibrations restricted to one plane), while longitudinal waves cannot.
items.example: Shaking a slinky spring up and down creates a transverse wave where coils move vertically while the wave travels horizontally. Pushing and pulling the slinky along its length creates a longitudinal wave with compressions (bunched coils) and rarefactions (stretched coils).

subtopic.name: Types of Waves
subtopic.what: This subtopic distinguishes between transverse and longitudinal waves based on the direction of vibration, and between mechanical and non-mechanical waves based on whether a medium is required for propagation.
subtopic.why: Classifying waves helps us understand their behaviour and applications. Light being a transverse non-mechanical wave explains why it can travel through the vacuum of space, while sound being a longitudinal mechanical wave explains why there is no sound in space.

items.title: I can distinguish between mechanical and non-mechanical waves
items.what: Mechanical waves require a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to propagate because they work by vibrating particles of matter. Non-mechanical waves, like electromagnetic waves, do not require a medium and can travel through a vacuum.
items.why: This explains why we can see the Sun but cannot hear explosions in space. Understanding this distinction is crucial for space communication and astronomy.
items.example: Sound is a mechanical wave that needs air molecules to travel, so astronauts in space suits must use radio (electromagnetic, non-mechanical) to communicate even when standing next to each other.

subtopic.name: Types of Waves
subtopic.what: This subtopic distinguishes between transverse and longitudinal waves based on the direction of vibration, and between mechanical and non-mechanical waves based on whether a medium is required for propagation.
subtopic.why: Classifying waves helps us understand their behaviour and applications. Light being a transverse non-mechanical wave explains why it can travel through the vacuum of space, while sound being a longitudinal mechanical wave explains why there is no sound in space.

items.title: I can explain that waves transfer energy without transferring matter
items.what: When a wave passes through a medium, the particles of the medium vibrate about their equilibrium positions but do not travel with the wave. Only energy is transferred from one location to another.
items.why: This principle explains why a cork bobs up and down on water waves but does not travel with the wave, and why sound can carry energy to your ear without wind blowing towards you.
items.example: In a stadium Mexican wave, each person stands and sits in sequence, but no person moves along the stadium. Similarly, water waves carry energy across the ocean while individual water molecules mostly move up and down in place.

subtopic.name: Types of Waves
subtopic.what: This subtopic distinguishes between transverse and longitudinal waves based on the direction of vibration, and between mechanical and non-mechanical waves based on whether a medium is required for propagation.
subtopic.why: Classifying waves helps us understand their behaviour and applications. Light being a transverse non-mechanical wave explains why it can travel through the vacuum of space, while sound being a longitudinal mechanical wave explains why there is no sound in space.

items.title: I can identify compressions and rarefactions in longitudinal waves
items.what: Compressions are regions where particles are closer together than normal (high pressure in sound waves). Rarefactions are regions where particles are more spread out than normal (low pressure in sound waves).
items.why: Compressions and rarefactions are how longitudinal waves carry energy. In sound, these pressure variations cause your eardrum to vibrate, allowing you to hear.
items.example: When a tuning fork vibrates, it pushes air molecules together (compression) then pulls back, allowing them to spread apart (rarefaction). These alternating regions travel outward at the speed of sound.

subtopic.name: Types of Waves
subtopic.what: This subtopic distinguishes between transverse and longitudinal waves based on the direction of vibration, and between mechanical and non-mechanical waves based on whether a medium is required for propagation.
subtopic.why: Classifying waves helps us understand their behaviour and applications. Light being a transverse non-mechanical wave explains why it can travel through the vacuum of space, while sound being a longitudinal mechanical wave explains why there is no sound in space.

items.title: I can describe electromagnetic waves as transverse vibrations of electric and magnetic fields
items.what: Electromagnetic waves consist of oscillating electric and magnetic fields that are perpendicular to each other and to the direction of wave travel. These waves do not require a medium and travel at speed c (3.00 × 10⁸ m/s) in a vacuum.
items.why: This model, developed by James Clerk Maxwell, unified electricity, magnetism, and optics into one theory. It explains how light can travel through the vacuum of space from the Sun to Earth.
items.example: In an electromagnetic wave travelling east, the electric field might oscillate vertically (up-down) while the magnetic field oscillates horizontally (north-south). Both fields oscillate at the same frequency.

subtopic.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the nature of electromagnetic waves as transverse vibrations of electric and magnetic fields, the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays, and the applications of each region in society.
subtopic.why: Electromagnetic radiation enables nearly all modern technology from mobile phones to medical imaging. Understanding the spectrum allows us to select the appropriate type of radiation for each application based on its wavelength and energy properties.

items.title: I can recall the approximate wavelength and frequency ranges of different spectrum regions
items.what: The electromagnetic spectrum ranges from radio waves (λ > 1 m, f < 300 MHz) through microwaves, infrared, visible light (400-700 nm), ultraviolet, X-rays, to gamma rays (λ < 10 pm, f > 3 × 10¹⁹ Hz).
items.why: Knowing the approximate ranges helps identify which technology or phenomenon involves which type of radiation, and allows quick estimation of wavelengths and frequencies.
items.example: Visible light occupies a tiny window from about 400 nm (violet) to 700 nm (red), corresponding to frequencies of approximately 4.3 × 10¹⁴ Hz to 7.5 × 10¹⁴ Hz.

subtopic.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the nature of electromagnetic waves as transverse vibrations of electric and magnetic fields, the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays, and the applications of each region in society.
subtopic.why: Electromagnetic radiation enables nearly all modern technology from mobile phones to medical imaging. Understanding the spectrum allows us to select the appropriate type of radiation for each application based on its wavelength and energy properties.

items.title: I can describe the electromagnetic radiation from the Sun as mainly UV, visible, and infrared
items.what: Solar radiation reaching Earth consists of approximately 7% ultraviolet, 44% visible light, and 48% infrared, with less than 1% from other wavelengths. The infrared component is responsible for most of Earth's warming.
items.why: Understanding the solar spectrum is essential for solar energy technology, climate science, and protecting ourselves from harmful UV radiation while benefiting from vitamin D production.
items.example: A solar panel is designed to absorb visible and infrared radiation (the majority of sunlight) to generate electricity, while sunscreen is designed to block the UV component that causes skin damage.

subtopic.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the nature of electromagnetic waves as transverse vibrations of electric and magnetic fields, the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays, and the applications of each region in society.
subtopic.why: Electromagnetic radiation enables nearly all modern technology from mobile phones to medical imaging. Understanding the spectrum allows us to select the appropriate type of radiation for each application based on its wavelength and energy properties.

items.title: I can give examples of societal uses for each region of the electromagnetic spectrum
items.what: Each region has specific applications: radio waves for communication and MRI; microwaves for cooking and radar; infrared for thermal imaging and remote controls; visible light for vision and lasers; UV for sterilisation; X-rays for medical imaging; gamma rays for cancer treatment.
items.why: Different wavelengths have different properties that make them suitable for different purposes. Longer wavelengths penetrate materials better, while shorter wavelengths carry more energy.
items.example: Airport security uses X-rays to see inside luggage because X-rays penetrate soft materials but are absorbed by dense objects like metal. Mobile phones use microwaves because they travel through walls but are absorbed by water (which is why they heat food).

subtopic.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the nature of electromagnetic waves as transverse vibrations of electric and magnetic fields, the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays, and the applications of each region in society.
subtopic.why: Electromagnetic radiation enables nearly all modern technology from mobile phones to medical imaging. Understanding the spectrum allows us to select the appropriate type of radiation for each application based on its wavelength and energy properties.

items.title: I can calculate wavelength or frequency of electromagnetic waves using c = fλ
items.what: For electromagnetic waves in a vacuum, the wave equation becomes c = fλ where c = 3.00 × 10⁸ m/s. This allows conversion between wavelength and frequency for any electromagnetic radiation.
items.why: Radio stations are identified by frequency (e.g., 100.3 MHz) but engineers need wavelength to design antennas. Medical equipment may specify X-ray wavelength but biologists need frequency to understand energy effects.
items.example: Radio station Nova broadcasts at 100.3 MHz. Its wavelength is λ = c/f = (3.00 × 10⁸)/(100.3 × 10⁶) = 2.99 m, which is why FM radio antennas are typically about 75 cm long (quarter wavelength).

subtopic.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the nature of electromagnetic waves as transverse vibrations of electric and magnetic fields, the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays, and the applications of each region in society.
subtopic.why: Electromagnetic radiation enables nearly all modern technology from mobile phones to medical imaging. Understanding the spectrum allows us to select the appropriate type of radiation for each application based on its wavelength and energy properties.

items.title: I can use a ray model with wave crests to describe reflection of light
items.what: When light reflects from a smooth surface, the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, both measured from the normal (perpendicular line). Wave crests approach and leave the surface at equal angles.
items.why: Understanding reflection allows us to predict where images form in mirrors and how much light is reflected at surfaces, which is crucial for designing everything from telescopes to car headlights.
items.example: A light ray hits a flat mirror at 40° to the normal. The reflected ray leaves at 40° on the other side of the normal. Wave crests arriving at this angle would show the same spacing before and after reflection.

subtopic.name: Reflection and Refraction
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how light behaves at boundaries between different media, including reflection (bouncing back) and refraction (bending). It introduces refractive index and Snell's law for quantitative analysis.
subtopic.why: Reflection and refraction explain everyday phenomena from mirrors and glasses to the apparent bending of objects in water. These principles are fundamental to designing optical instruments, corrective lenses, and fibre optic systems.

items.title: I can define refractive index and explain what it measures
items.what: Refractive index (n) is defined as n = c/v, where c is the speed of light in a vacuum and v is the speed of light in the medium. It measures how much slower light travels in a material compared to a vacuum.
items.why: Refractive index allows us to compare materials and predict how much light will bend at interfaces. Higher refractive index means slower light speed and greater bending towards the normal.
items.example: Water has n = 1.33, meaning light travels 1.33 times slower in water than in a vacuum. Diamond has n = 2.42, so light travels 2.42 times slower in diamond, which is why diamonds sparkle so much.

subtopic.name: Reflection and Refraction
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how light behaves at boundaries between different media, including reflection (bouncing back) and refraction (bending). It introduces refractive index and Snell's law for quantitative analysis.
subtopic.why: Reflection and refraction explain everyday phenomena from mirrors and glasses to the apparent bending of objects in water. These principles are fundamental to designing optical instruments, corrective lenses, and fibre optic systems.

items.title: I can use the relationship n₁v₁ = n₂v₂ at media boundaries
items.what: When light crosses from one medium to another, the product of refractive index and speed remains constant because frequency does not change. This can be written as n₁v₁ = n₂v₂ or v₁/v₂ = n₂/n₁.
items.why: This relationship allows us to calculate the speed of light in any transparent material if we know its refractive index, without directly measuring it.
items.example: Light travels at 3.00 × 10⁸ m/s in air (n = 1.00) and enters glass (n = 1.50). Using n₁v₁ = n₂v₂: v₂ = (1.00 × 3.00 × 10⁸)/1.50 = 2.00 × 10⁸ m/s in the glass.

subtopic.name: Reflection and Refraction
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how light behaves at boundaries between different media, including reflection (bouncing back) and refraction (bending). It introduces refractive index and Snell's law for quantitative analysis.
subtopic.why: Reflection and refraction explain everyday phenomena from mirrors and glasses to the apparent bending of objects in water. These principles are fundamental to designing optical instruments, corrective lenses, and fibre optic systems.

items.title: I can apply Snell's law to analyse refraction situations
items.what: Snell's law states n₁sin(θ₁) = n₂sin(θ₂), relating the angles and refractive indices at a boundary. When light enters a denser medium (higher n), it bends towards the normal; when entering a less dense medium, it bends away.
items.why: Snell's law is essential for designing lenses, prisms, and optical instruments. It explains why pools look shallower than they are and why spear fishers must aim below the apparent fish position.
items.example: Light in air (n = 1.00) hits water (n = 1.33) at 45° to the normal. Using Snell's law: sin(θ₂) = (1.00 × sin45°)/1.33 = 0.531, so θ₂ = 32°. The light bends towards the normal.

subtopic.name: Reflection and Refraction
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how light behaves at boundaries between different media, including reflection (bouncing back) and refraction (bending). It introduces refractive index and Snell's law for quantitative analysis.
subtopic.why: Reflection and refraction explain everyday phenomena from mirrors and glasses to the apparent bending of objects in water. These principles are fundamental to designing optical instruments, corrective lenses, and fibre optic systems.

items.title: I can use a ray model to explain the formation of images due to refraction
items.what: When light from an underwater object refracts at the water surface, the rays bend away from the normal. An observer traces these rays back in straight lines to see an image that appears closer to the surface than the actual object.
items.why: This explains optical illusions like the bent pencil in water and helps us understand how lenses form images. It is crucial for understanding how our eyes work and how to correct vision problems.
items.example: A coin at the bottom of a mug is invisible from certain angles. When water is added, refraction bends light rays from the coin upward, creating an image that appears to float higher, making the coin visible.

subtopic.name: Reflection and Refraction
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how light behaves at boundaries between different media, including reflection (bouncing back) and refraction (bending). It introduces refractive index and Snell's law for quantitative analysis.
subtopic.why: Reflection and refraction explain everyday phenomena from mirrors and glasses to the apparent bending of objects in water. These principles are fundamental to designing optical instruments, corrective lenses, and fibre optic systems.

items.title: I can explain when partial internal reflection occurs
items.what: When light hits a boundary between two media, some light is always reflected and some is transmitted (refracted). This partial internal reflection occurs at any angle of incidence, though the reflected portion is usually small (about 4% for glass-air).
items.why: Partial reflection explains why you can see your reflection in a window while also seeing through it. Understanding this helps in designing anti-reflective coatings and beam splitters.
items.example: When you look at a shop window, you see both the display inside (transmitted light) and your own reflection (partially reflected light). At night, with the shop dark inside, your reflection becomes more visible.

subtopic.name: Total Internal Reflection
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the conditions for total internal reflection, the concept of critical angle, and applications including optical fibres for communication.
subtopic.why: Total internal reflection enables modern telecommunications through optical fibres, which carry internet data at the speed of light with minimal signal loss. It also explains the sparkle of diamonds and is used in medical endoscopes.

items.title: I can define and calculate the critical angle using Snell's law
items.what: The critical angle (θc) is the angle of incidence at which the refracted ray travels along the boundary (θ₂ = 90°). Using Snell's law: n₁sin(θc) = n₂sin(90°) = n₂, so sin(θc) = n₂/n₁. Critical angle only exists when light travels from higher to lower refractive index.
items.why: The critical angle determines when total internal reflection will occur. Materials with higher refractive indices have smaller critical angles, making them better at trapping light internally.
items.example: For water (n = 1.33) to air (n = 1.00): sin(θc) = 1.00/1.33 = 0.752, so θc = 48.8°. Any light ray hitting the water surface from below at an angle greater than 48.8° will be totally internally reflected.

subtopic.name: Total Internal Reflection
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the conditions for total internal reflection, the concept of critical angle, and applications including optical fibres for communication.
subtopic.why: Total internal reflection enables modern telecommunications through optical fibres, which carry internet data at the speed of light with minimal signal loss. It also explains the sparkle of diamonds and is used in medical endoscopes.

items.title: I can explain the conditions for total internal reflection
items.what: Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium of higher refractive index to lower refractive index, and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle. Under these conditions, all light is reflected with no refraction.
items.why: Total internal reflection is 100% efficient with no energy loss, unlike reflection from mirrors which absorb some light. This makes it ideal for transmitting signals over long distances in optical fibres.
items.example: A scuba diver looking up at angles greater than 48.8° from vertical sees a perfect mirror-like reflection of the underwater scene, not the sky above. This is total internal reflection at the water-air boundary.

subtopic.name: Total Internal Reflection
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the conditions for total internal reflection, the concept of critical angle, and applications including optical fibres for communication.
subtopic.why: Total internal reflection enables modern telecommunications through optical fibres, which carry internet data at the speed of light with minimal signal loss. It also explains the sparkle of diamonds and is used in medical endoscopes.

items.title: I can explain how optical fibres use total internal reflection for communication
items.what: Optical fibres have a high refractive index core surrounded by lower refractive index cladding. Light enters at angles that exceed the critical angle, bouncing along the fibre by repeated total internal reflections with minimal energy loss.
items.why: Optical fibres can carry data at the speed of light over hundreds of kilometres with very little signal degradation. They form the backbone of internet infrastructure and are immune to electromagnetic interference.
items.example: A fibre with core n = 1.58 and cladding n = 1.55 has critical angle sin(θc) = 1.55/1.58 = 0.981, so θc = 79°. Light entering within 11° of the fibre axis will be totally internally reflected and travel the length of the fibre.

subtopic.name: Total Internal Reflection
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the conditions for total internal reflection, the concept of critical angle, and applications including optical fibres for communication.
subtopic.why: Total internal reflection enables modern telecommunications through optical fibres, which carry internet data at the speed of light with minimal signal loss. It also explains the sparkle of diamonds and is used in medical endoscopes.

items.title: I can apply Snell's law to analyse optical fibre operation quantitatively
items.what: For an optical fibre to work, the core must have a higher refractive index than the cladding. The critical angle determines the maximum angle at which light can enter and still be guided. Small differences in refractive index create large critical angles.
items.why: Engineers must carefully select core and cladding materials to achieve the desired critical angle. Too small a difference makes the fibre very sensitive to bending; too large reduces the number of paths light can take.
items.example: If a fibre needs θc = 82°, and the core has n = 1.66, then the cladding must have n = 1.66 × sin(82°) = 1.64. This small difference (0.02) still allows total internal reflection at steep angles.

subtopic.name: Total Internal Reflection
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the conditions for total internal reflection, the concept of critical angle, and applications including optical fibres for communication.
subtopic.why: Total internal reflection enables modern telecommunications through optical fibres, which carry internet data at the speed of light with minimal signal loss. It also explains the sparkle of diamonds and is used in medical endoscopes.

items.title: I can explain why colour dispersion occurs in prisms
items.what: Different colours (wavelengths) of light travel at slightly different speeds in glass, giving each colour a slightly different refractive index. Violet light is slowed more than red, so it refracts more. This separates white light into a spectrum.
items.why: Dispersion was key to Newton's discovery that white light is composed of all colours. It is used in spectrometers to analyse light from stars and identify chemical elements.
items.example: In crown glass, red light (640 nm) has n = 1.509 while violet light (434 nm) has n = 1.521. When white light enters a prism at 45°, red refracts to about 28.1° while violet refracts to about 27.6°, separating the colours.

subtopic.name: Dispersion and Optical Phenomena
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers colour dispersion in prisms and lenses, chromatic distortion, and natural optical phenomena including rainbows and mirages.
subtopic.why: Dispersion explains why prisms create rainbows and why simple lenses produce colour fringing. Understanding these phenomena helps in designing colour-corrected optical systems and explains beautiful natural displays like rainbows.

items.title: I can explain chromatic distortion in lenses and how it is corrected
items.what: Because different colours focus at different distances from a lens, simple lenses produce images with coloured fringes (chromatic distortion). Combining lenses made from different glasses with different dispersions can cancel out this effect.
items.why: Chromatic distortion limits the quality of telescopes, cameras, and microscopes. Understanding it led to the development of achromatic lenses that produce sharp, colour-free images.
items.example: In a simple magnifying glass, blue light focuses closer to the lens than red. Looking at a white edge, you see blue fringing on one side and red on the other. Camera lenses use 6-15 elements to correct this.

subtopic.name: Dispersion and Optical Phenomena
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers colour dispersion in prisms and lenses, chromatic distortion, and natural optical phenomena including rainbows and mirages.
subtopic.why: Dispersion explains why prisms create rainbows and why simple lenses produce colour fringing. Understanding these phenomena helps in designing colour-corrected optical systems and explains beautiful natural displays like rainbows.

items.title: I can explain the formation of rainbows using refraction and reflection
items.what: Rainbows form when sunlight enters water droplets, refracts (dispersing colours), reflects off the back of the droplet, and refracts again on exit. Different colours exit at slightly different angles, with red at about 42° and violet at about 40° from the anti-solar point.
items.why: Rainbows demonstrate dispersion in nature and show how multiple optical effects combine. Understanding rainbow formation explains why they always appear opposite the Sun and why secondary rainbows have reversed colours.
items.example: The primary rainbow forms from one internal reflection in raindrops. Red appears on the outside (42°) and violet on the inside (40°). A secondary rainbow, fainter and with reversed colours, forms from two internal reflections at about 51°.

subtopic.name: Dispersion and Optical Phenomena
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers colour dispersion in prisms and lenses, chromatic distortion, and natural optical phenomena including rainbows and mirages.
subtopic.why: Dispersion explains why prisms create rainbows and why simple lenses produce colour fringing. Understanding these phenomena helps in designing colour-corrected optical systems and explains beautiful natural displays like rainbows.

items.title: I can explain the formation of mirages using refraction in air layers
items.what: Mirages form when light passes through air layers at different temperatures, which have different refractive indices. Hot air near a road has lower refractive index, causing light to gradually bend upward, creating an inverted image that looks like water reflection.
items.why: Mirages demonstrate that refraction occurs continuously in media with varying properties, not just at sharp boundaries. Understanding mirages helps explain atmospheric optical effects and limitations of long-range observations.
items.example: On a hot road, air near the surface is warmer (lower n) than air above. Light from a distant car bends gradually upward through these layers, eventually undergoing total internal reflection. The observer sees an inverted image below the road surface, resembling a reflection in water.

subtopic.name: Dispersion and Optical Phenomena
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers colour dispersion in prisms and lenses, chromatic distortion, and natural optical phenomena including rainbows and mirages.
subtopic.why: Dispersion explains why prisms create rainbows and why simple lenses produce colour fringing. Understanding these phenomena helps in designing colour-corrected optical systems and explains beautiful natural displays like rainbows.

items.title: I can distinguish between inferior and superior mirages
items.what: Inferior mirages (image below the object) occur when the surface is hotter than the air above, common over hot roads. Superior mirages (image above the object) occur when the surface is cooler, common over cold water, making distant objects appear to float.
items.why: Different temperature gradients create different types of mirages. Superior mirages can make objects beyond the horizon visible, which has historically confused sailors and explorers.
items.example: The hot road mirage is an inferior mirage showing sky reflected below, looking like water. A ship seen floating above the horizon over cold Arctic water is a superior mirage, caused by cool air near the water surface bending light downward.

subtopic.why: Dispersion explains why prisms create rainbows and why simple lenses produce colour fringing. Understanding these phenomena helps in designing colour-corrected optical systems and explains beautiful natural displays like rainbows.
